title: The Wall Street Journal: GE to Sell part of healthcare business to Veritas Capital for $1.05 billion
text:
Published: Apr 2, 2018 2:36 p.m. ET Share 
New private-equity owner to transition the value-based care division to a stand-alone company Bloomberg 
By Aisha Al-Muslim 
General Electric Co. has reached a deal to sell part of its health-care information-technology business to private-equity firm Veritas Capital for $1.05 billion in cash, the latest move from the conglomerate to streamline its operations. 
Veritas said Monday that an affiliate entered into an agreement to buy GE Healthcareâ€™s value-based care division, comprising of Enterprise Financial Management, Ambulatory Care Management and Workforce Management, formerly API Healthcare. 
Veritas said it would work alongside GE GE, -3.38% management to transition the business into a stand-alone company. The transaction is expected to close during the third quarter. 
GE Healthcare, which provides software and other tools for things like medical-records and image management as well as human-resource and payroll services, is the $19 billion health-care business of GE. The company built up the business through a series of acquisitions including its $1.2 billion purchase of IDX Systems Corp. in 2006.
